channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Win 'means world to me' - Murray
item.description: Andy Murray says his US Open win "means the world" after ending Britain's long search for another male Grand Slam champion.

item.title: Heads say exam watchdog 'failed'
item.description: GCSE English grades were unfair, MPs are told by head teachers - but Ofqual says it played its "proper part".

item.title: UK cities set to get 4G this year
item.description: The UK's first fourth generation mobile service - known as 4G - will launch in 16 cities this year, operator Everything Everywhere announces.

item.title: Bin Laden raid doctor speaks out
item.description: The Pakistani doctor involved in the US search for Osama Bin Laden tells Fox News he was unaware that the al-Qaeda leader was their target.

item.title: Three die in festival coach crash
item.description: Three people die and others are seriously injured as a Merseyside coach taking people home from a festival crashes in Surrey.

item.title: G4S not paid since July - Locog
item.description: Olympic security firm G4S has not been paid since 13 July - just after it revealed it could not deliver the number of staff needed for the Games, says London 2012 organiser.

item.title: Charles van Commenee to step down
item.description: Charles van Commenee is to step down as UK Athletics head coach after the team failed to meet his own medal target at London 2012.

item.title: Fresh arrest in payments probe
item.description: A 31-year-old prison officer is arrested by police investigating alleged corrupt payments to public officials.

item.title: Rescue package for troubled trust
item.description: Experts are called in to help Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust, accused of "appalling standards of care" three years ago.

item.title: Cable to confirm business bank
item.description: Vince Cable is to confirm that the government is moving ahead with plans for a government-backed "business bank" to boost lending to UK firms.

item.title: US 'covered up' Soviet massacre
item.description: Newly released documents appear to back the idea that the US helped cover up Soviet responsibility for the 1940 massacre of Polish soldiers at Katyn.

item.title: William and Kate visit Singapore
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are beginning a tour of South East Asia and the South Pacific as part of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee celebrations.

item.title: Brad Pitt: No more big salaries
item.description: Brad Pitt says actors can no longer expect multi-million dollar salaries, as studios are "challenged because of the economic downturn".

item.title: UK universities in world top six
item.description: UK universities take four of the top six slots in a global university "league table", although Cambridge is down one place to second.

item.title: Barclays new boss pledges reforms
item.description: The new boss of Barclays, Antony Jenkins, vows to be quick and bold with reforms, but says he will not break up the bank.

item.title: House price changes 'are masked'
item.description: A broadly flat trend in house prices in the UK masks significant regional variations, according to surveyors.

item.title: Davis and Fox back new Tory group
item.description: Tory big hitters Liam Fox and David Davis throw their weight behind a new group pushing for a "clear" Conservative message at the next election.

item.title: Field: Welfare reforms a disaster
item.description: Iain Duncan Smith's Universal Credit is heading for "disaster", warns Labour MP Frank Field who helped craft government welfare policy.

item.title: Asian and African diabetes risk
item.description: British people of South Asian, African or African Caribbean descent are significantly more likely to develop Type 2 diabetes than their European counterparts, researchers have warned.

item.title: New approach to hay fever vaccine
item.description: Researchers in London believe they have developed a new approach that could lead to a cheaper and more effective vaccine for hay fever.

item.title: UK schools 'most segregated'
item.description: Schools in the UK are among the most socially segregated in the developed world, according to a major annual international education report.

item.title: Ofqual 'ordered late GCSE change'
item.description: Leaked letters reveal Ofqual ordered an exam board to change English GCSE grade boundaries against its will two weeks before the results were published.

item.title: GoDaddy sites suffer disruption
item.description: Thousands of websites hosted by one of the world's biggest internet domain registrars and web hosts, GoDaddy, are downed.

item.title: Music streamer swings to profit
item.description: Omnifone, the firm that powers Sony and Blackberry music services, swings to profit, news it links to a crackdown on piracy.

item.title: England badger cull court appeal
item.description: Badgers could be shot across England within weeks, barring a last minute legal challenge.

item.title: Antarctic molluscs 'switch sex'
item.description: Antarctic bivalves have surprised scientists who have discovered that the animals switch sex.

item.title: Mantel makes Man Booker shortlist
item.description: Man Booker-winning author Hilary Mantel is shortlisted for the Â£50,000 literary prize again, for her sequel to Wolf Hall, which won the award in 2009.

item.title: Full Strictly line-up confirmed
item.description: TV presenters Johnny Ball and Fern Britton are among the 14 celebrities who will take part in this year's Strictly Come Dancing.

item.title: Why doesn't everyone know who Nikola Tesla was?
item.description: Fans have rallied to buy the lab of inventor and electricity pioneer Nikola Tesla to turn it into a museum. But why do so few people appreciate the importance of Tesla's work?

item.title: Tegart: A tough cop in a tough world
item.description: When the British sought to quell unrest in Palestine in the 1930s, they turned to an uncompromising Irish policeman, who came up with a drastic and expensive solution - a line of fortresses that to this day bear the marks of their painful past.

item.title: More to come from Murray - Lendl
item.description: Coach Ivan Lendl is optimistic that Andy Murray's US Open win will lead to more Grand Slam victories for the Briton.

item.title: Welsh plight 'weighs' on Coleman
item.description: Wales manager Chris Coleman admits concern over his side's goalless streak ahead of Tuesday's World Cup qualifier in Serbia.

item.title: Vettel 'deserved penalty' for Alonso move
item.description: Sebastian Vettel's swerve at Fernando Alonso in Italy was too aggressive, says ex-F1 driver Jaime Alguersuari

item.title: Pooley considers quitting cycling
item.description: Norfolk cyclist Emma Pooley could quit the sport after next week's World Championships in the Netherlands.

item.title: London 2012 zoomable image: Team GB's victory parade
item.description: Explore a photo of Team GB's Olympians and Paralympians outside Buckingham Palace after a victory parade through the streets of London.

item.title: In pictures: The Greatest Team Parade
item.description: Some memorable images of the day Olympic and Paralympic athletes are carried on floats through central London, cheered on by thousands of fans.

item.title: Relive summer's best sporting moments
item.description: BBC Sport's top moments from a summer that included the London Olympics and Paralympics, plus a British Wimbledon men's finalist

item.title: What next for the Olympic Park?
item.description: The doors are shut and work is under way to transform the park and its venues into housing and public sporting facilities, the first of which is due to open in July 2013.

item.title: Rio up and running for 2016 Paralympic Games
item.description: Rio de Janeiro, which started its road to the 2016 Paralympics back in 1999, is now in the global spotlight after being handed the Games baton by London.

item.title: In which countries did Paralympians outperform Olympians?
item.description: Why did China thrash the US in the Paralympics?

item.title: VIDEO: Aerial tribute to London 2012 athletes
item.description: Britain's Olympic and Paralympic athletes have been honoured with a flypast over Buckingham Palace, after a victory parade through London.

item.title: VIDEO: The volunteers who made the Games
item.description: The 70,000 Olympic volunteers, or Games Makers, have been widely praised for their work on London 2012.

item.title: Massacre suspect wants to return
item.description: A man who returned from a prison in Africa after suspected involvement in a massacre says he wants to go back.

item.title: Murderer 'warned he was a danger'
item.description: A man who stabbed his ex-lover to death warned he was "a danger to himself and others", his family claim.

item.title: Murray's home town celebrates win
item.description: The Stirlingshire town of Dunblane celebrates as their famous son Andy Murray becomes the first Scot and the first Briton since 1936 to win a grand slam tennis championship.

item.title: Air ambulance called to M8 crash
item.description: A serious crash on the M8 Glasgow to Edinburgh motorway closes the road in both directions near Harthill services.

item.title: Arrest after guns 'found in car'
item.description: A 52-year-old man is arrested as police investigating dissident republican terrorism stop and search a car on the main A1 Belfast to Dublin road.

item.title: Diabetic boy 'unable to start P1'
item.description: The parents of a four-year-old boy with diabetes say their son has not been able to start primary school because of issues over staff training.

item.title: Examiners seek urgent GCSE talks
item.description: The WJEC examining board wants further urgent talks over the education minister's demand that GCSE English papers be regraded for hundreds of pupils.

item.title: Swiss airline ends Cardiff flight
item.description: A Swiss airline has withdrawn its flights from Cardiff to Zurich for the winter citing low passenger numbers last year as the reason.

item.title: Somalia election a 'great step'
item.description: International leaders, including British Prime Minister David Cameron, hail the election of Hassan Sheikh Mohamud as a "great step forward" for Somalia.

item.title: Kenya curfew after ethnic clashes
item.description: Violence continues in Kenya's Tana River area despite a dusk-to-dawn curfew after the deaths of 112 people in weeks of clashes.

item.title: China sends ships in islands row
item.description: Two Chinese patrol ships are sent to islands disputed with Japan, which has just completed a deal to buy the territory, state media in China say.

item.title: Three dead in Bagram base attack
item.description: Three Afghans are killed at the Bagram air base in Afghanistan, in an attack claimed by the Taliban.

item.title: Spain opposes bailout conditions
item.description: Spain's Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy says his government will not accept conditions from outside over a possible bailout.

item.title: Istanbul rocked by deadly blast
item.description: A suicide bombing outside a police station in the Turkish city of Istanbul kills a policeman and leaves several people injured.

item.title: Amazon massacre claim withdrawn
item.description: Campaign group Survival International, which carried reports of a mass killing of Yanomami indigenous people in Venezuela, says it now believes no such attack took place.

item.title: Rio police investigate murders
item.description: Police in Brazil are investigating the deaths of six teenagers whose bodies were found on a road being widened for Rio's 2016 Olympics.

item.title: Yemen minister survives attack
item.description: Yemen's defence minister survives an assassination attempt which kills at least five of his bodyguards, reports say.

item.title: Turkey 'will not return Iraq VP'
item.description: Turkey's Prime Minister Erdogan says he will not send Iraqi Vice-President Tariq al-Hashemi back to Iraq, where he has been sentenced to death in absentia.

item.title: US to mark 11th 9/11 anniversary
item.description: Memorials are due to be held in New York, Washington and Pennsylvania to mark the 11th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.

item.title: Chicago schools in teacher strike
item.description: Teachers in Chicago go on strike for the first time in 25 years, setting up a showdown with Mayor Rahm Emanuel over pay and conditions.

item.title: Day in pictures: 10 September 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 10 September 2012

item.title: In pictures: The Queen's corgis
item.description: A look back at the Queen and her corgis

item.title: In pictures: Nicaragua volcano erupts
item.description: Nicaragua volcanoforces evacuation

item.title: Week in pictures: 1-7 September 2012
item.description: News photos: 1-7 September 2012

item.title: Day in pictures: 6 September 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 6 September 2012

item.title: Your pictures: Music
item.description: Readers' pictures on the theme of music

item.title: In pictures: Cecil Beaton's war
item.description: World War II for the Ministry of Information

item.title: In pictures: Musicians jam aboard the Africa Express
item.description: 80 leading musicians touring the UK for a week

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Business Secretary Vince Cable has rejected suggestions that ideological divisions within his ministerial team are hampering efforts to bolster UK economic growth.

item.title: AUDIO: The moment Murray won the US Open
item.description: Listen to commentary from 5 live's Jonathan Overend and Jeff Tarango as Andy Murray becomes the first British man to win a Grand Slam title in 76 years.

item.title: VIDEO: Dunblane's joy at Murray victory
item.description: Dunblane is celebrating after local hero Andy Murray won a historic victory in the US Open - the first British man to win a singles Grand Slam championship for 76 years.

item.title: VIDEO: Murray 'relieved' after US Open win
item.description: Andy Murray ends Britain's 76-year wait for a male Grand Slam singles champion with an epic victory over Novak Djokovic in the US Open final.

item.title: VIDEO: Growing up on a tough estate
item.description: Panorama meets some of the young people growing up on a tough estate in tough times

item.title: VIDEO: Blootered? New words in dictionary
item.description: Around 80 new words have been added to the Collins online dictionary - and some of the new additions, such as blootered and frenemy, have been put to the test.

item.title: VIDEO: Three die in festival coach crash
item.description: Three people were killed and a number of others seriously injured when a coach returning from a festival overturned after crashing into a tree near a tunnel in Surrey.

item.title: VIDEO: Call Me Maybe singer on new single
item.description: Carly Rae Jepsen is hoping to repeat her 'Call Me Maybe' success with her new single, 'Good Time.'

item.title: VIDEO: '4G could be 20 times faster'
item.description: Technology expert Paul Vlissidis discusses the likely impact of 4G access for the UK, as mobile operator Everything Everywhere is expected to announce a rollout of the service.

item.title: How do people view the wheelchair?
item.description: Do people now view the wheelchair differently?

item.title: Rediscovering forgotten confidence
item.description: How Britain rediscovered its forgotten confidence

item.title: Why I secretly recorded my life
item.description: 'Why I secretly recorded my life for three years'

item.title: In which countries is Coca-Cola not sold?
item.description: Which countries still don't sell Coca-Cola?

item.title: Ghost story spooks 40 years on
item.description: How a childhood ghost story inspired a horror film

item.title: Tory chairman is related to punk legend
item.description: Tory chief has survived cancer and his cousin is a punk icon

item.title: Scotland's salmon farm dilemma
item.description: Scotland's struggle to meet world demand for salmon
